FacilityName: City of Fort Walton Beach WWTP

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
The approach of the WWTP to chemical safety is prevention. This is accomplished by ensuring all personnel are properly trained in operational and safety procedures for any chemicals used by plant personnel. The WWTP also conducts regular facility and equipment self-inspections to ensure proper function. A policy of preventive maintenance is also followed to keep equipment in good working order. The City Council has identified safety as a prime concern and has established a safety policy by pass ordinances requiring all departments to establish and maintain safety programs. To help with this, a Safety Council has been established and meets on a regular basis (usually quarterly).

FACILITY AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES
The City of Fort Walton Beach Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP) has the capacity to treat up to 11.5 million gallons per day (MGD) of wastewater per day with an average flow of 4.5 MGD.  Wastewater enters the Facility from two (2) main pump stations located off-site. The wastewater enters the plant at the headworks, where it is aerated and de-gritted in the aeration chamber. From there the wastewater enters two (2) primary clarifiers for primary sedimentation. The wastewater then undergoes biological treatment by passing through a series of Rotating Biological Contactors (RBCs), on its way to the two (2) secondary clarifiers for further sedimentation. The wastewater then undergoes disinfection before being discharged into a 20 MG holding pond. From the pond the wastewater is either broadcast onto the plant?s 450 acre sprayfield or, with further treatment, pumped to a 2 MG holding tank located at the City Golf Course for broadcast. The Wastewater Treatment Plant has one independent chlorine injection system, which is used during the disinfection phase of wastewater treatment.  The system has one (1) one-ton container of chlorine on line and one (1) one-ton cylinder on standby at any one time.  The WWTP operat

es a vacuum system using gaseous chlorine.  Chlorine is fed under vacuum from a one-ton cylinder through a Regal 7000 Smart Valve Series 7000 automatic switch-over system.  The WWTP normally maintains a maximum of 6 one-ton cylinders at the site at any one time.  All full and empty cylinders are stored outdoors on a loading dock with a roof to shield the cylinders from the sun.  During chlorine deliveries, the delivery truck backs up to the unloading area and unloads the cylinders using the WWTP?s crane.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
  The procedures/policies in this section are drawn, in part, from such rules and regulations as 40 CFR 68, 29 CFR 1910.119, the OSHA PSM and other federal, state and local ordinances.
All employees presently involved in operating chlorine related aspects of the treatment process, and prior to being involved in operating a newly assigned process, undergo training specific to their job tasks.  The training includes an overview of the specific process and the operating procedures involved.  The training also includes emphasis on the specific safety and health hazards, emergency operations including shutdown, and safe work practices applicable to the employee's job tasks.
Each employee is provided with written operating procedures containing clear instructions for safely conducting activities involved in his/her specific job tasks. The written procedures are readily accessible to employees who work on or maintain a process.  Furthermore, the operating procedures are reviewed as often as necessary to assure that they reflect current operating practice. This includes changes that result from modifications to process chemicals, technology, and equipment, and modifications to adjacent or ancillary facilities.  The WWTP certifies annually that these operating procedures are current and accurate. 
  Written operating procedures for safe work practices that address the control of hazards are also pr

refresher training and if, in concert with its employees, the WWTP determines that refresher training is required more frequently than every year, it will implement a new refresher-training schedule.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
The City has had no reportable releases of chlorine.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The City of Fort Walton Beach is not required to develop an Emergency Response Plan (ERP) for the Fort Walton Beach Wastewater Treatment Plant because the Fort Walton Beach Fire Department will serve as their primary responder.  No Fort Walton Beach Wastewater Treatment Plant personnel will respond if there is a chlorine gas release.  Since the WWTP has chosen not to respond to accidental releases itself, the Fort Walton Beach WWTP has coordinated with local planning and response agencies, and established mechanisms for notifying emergency responders when the need for a response occurs (40 CFR 68.90). The WWTP?s role in a major chlorine incident is primarily limited to notification and evacuation of plant personnel. As previously stated, minor leaks and major leaks will be handled by the fire department.  Rescue of injured or disabled personnel are restricted to fire department employees aided by plant personnel where necessary.  Evacuations outside of the plant are performed by the fire, and/or police departments in coordination with the emergency management agency.  
  The State of Florida statutes require all spills or releases to the environment must be reported to the Department of Environmental Protection.  The plant manager should make this call as soon as possible after the time of release.  A spill form will be completed for use in mailing the report.  A spill report letter should be mailed within 24 hours of the release.
If 10 lbs. or more of chlorine is released to the environment, the National Response Center (NRC) (1 800 424 8802) must also be contacted.  It is the responsibility of the Manager and Assistant Manager of the WWTP to contact the NRC.

The WWTP conducts periodic drills to prepare for response to potential chlorine releases.  The purpose of these drills is to familiarize local emergency response agencies with the facilities and to test on-site emergency response procedures. For all chlorine emergency incidents and drills, a critique of the response is completed.  The critique consists of at least one meeting with all of the WWTP responders attending.  A review of the entire incident and response is conducted and problems that arose during the incident are addressed and solutions sought.
PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
The WWTP is scheduled for a major upgrade within the very near future in which all systems and equipment will be repaired or replaced. The initial phases of this have been completed and work should begin soon.
